text: A MOSQUITO alights on a human arm. The stinger injects in the warm flesh. The insectile body becomes full and red as it sucks the b The fist of the arm clenches. The forearm muscles tighten. Trapping the stinger. The mosquito struggles to pull its needlike appendage fre The tendons of the arm hold it firm. Forcing blood into it. The insect struggles. Blood engorges it, swelling its body. It swells. Swells. POPS in a SPRITZ of blood.
Dumb suck.

CALEB COLTON is stretched out on the beat up, broke down Ford Pickup. Cowboy boots crossed on the transom. Hat dipped low over his face. He is a strapping young farmboy of 18. Long, dusty, shoulder length hair. An all-American, milkbread, midwestern farm kid. Bored off his ass. He yawns and swings off the back of the truck.

The pickup is a funnel of dust on the thin strip of road. The wide open, bleak emptiness of the fields as far as th can see. An awesome country sunset spreading out across the sprawl barren landscape in fingers of red shadows.

The Ford Pickup drifts into town. Sweeping past a dirty, disheveled metal sign reading, "We to Fix, Oklahoma. Pop. 274." Slowing down along the Main street which is a long strip service road running off the highway. A single gas station. A Pit Stop Burger joint with cars parked outside.  A huge granary with tall, stilt silos. If you're driving by and you blink, you miss it. The boy in the Pickup cruises into the Pit Stop.

Tacky bright orange day glo neon type of place. Couple other FARM KIDS in pickups and jeeps pulled in. Lounging around, smoking cigarettes, swigging beer. The Pickup cuts a curve into the parking space in a showe gravel. Caleb jumps out. Has a casual look around him. Like he wouldn't piss if his pants were on fire. He lights up a Marlboro. Deep heels it up to the window. Leans back on his elbows on the counter. The orange haired WAITRESS behind the window looks irrita at the farmboy.
You gonna stand there or you gonna order? Caleb speaks over his shoulder.

If I never see another burger again I'll be happy. The waitress shakes her head. The farmboy distractedly eyes the lanky, rangy kids lopin him. One with freckles on his face, LEVON, knocks Caleb's hat head. Caleb catches his hat and socks the boy in the arm.
What's eating' you?
Your Mama. Y' oughta keep an eye on her, Levon.
You wish.
Wish I may, wish I might, wish I be hundred thousand miles from here tonight. Goddamn straight.
Take off.
Might just. The farmboy's gaze drifts across the street to the...

Lit blue and white beneath bright fluorescent bulbs. A GIRL turns from the window. An ice cream cone in her hand. A tiny line of the frosty cream dripping down the side of mouth. Caleb stares at the girl. She runs a hand through thick, shiny brown hair, brushing back off her forehead. Exposing her face. Heart shaped. Impossibly pale skin in the fluorescent glow. Wide eyes, a depthless ice blue like a sunny, summer sky. A small mouth out of which a narrow red tongue swipes at melting cone in her hands. She looks to be in her late teens. A faded cowboy shirt fits snugly across her chest. A pair of Levis meet a dusty pair of black cowboy boots. Those blue eyes lift and light on Caleb's face.
A shiver runs up Caleb's spine. A shiver that feels good. He claps Levon on the shoulder, nodding his head toward t at the Tasty Freeze.
I'm in love.
I'm dreaming.
Keep dreaming. Caleb pushes away from the counter and walks across the s
The fluorescent light catches the girl's eye and blazes a turns her back. Caleb pulls into position beside her.  He hesitates, suddenly loosing his nerve. Then the swagger returns.

Excuse me, but I'm a little lost. Could you tell me where the nearest Tasty Freeze is? I'm just dyin' for a cone. The girl looks around. Caleb's breath catches in his throat. Those ice blue eyes gazing up at him.
Dying? Caleb gazes into that face that lights up the night.
It's hot out.
This is cold. Referring to the ice cream cone.
Could I have a bite?
A bite? Caleb shifts weight from one foot to the other nervously. Working hard. Mind scrambling.
I never seen you before. You're not from around here are you?
No.
Got a name?
Mae. Caleb swallows. His face turns hot. Mae's eyes skate to his face. And shimmer.
Where you from, Mae? She wipes her mouth with the back of her hand.
Ever hear of Sweetwater?
That's down in Texas, ain't it?
Yeah.
Who you here with?
Friends.
Boyfriend?
Friends. She looks Caleb in the eyes.
I'm staying out at the trailer park near the highway. I need a lift home. Caleb looks at her a long moment. Looking like he died and went to heaven.
Caleb opens the door for Mae. Helps her up into her seat. Then climbs behind the wheel.
The farmboy FIRES up the engine. Steers out onto the road.
My name's, Caleb.
That's a nice name.

Y'sure are pretty, but I guess a lot of people tell you that. She looks away out the windshield. Hard to read. Soon it's just the two of them driving down the dark and deserted highway. He looks at her. His breath sticks in his throat. Mae is unearthly beautiful in the haloish haze of the das lights. Her eyes shift to him.
You got a boyfriend?
Sometimes.
What about other times?
What about them?
Well, I don't have a girlfriend.
Too bad.
How long you planning to stay around here?
Not long.
But you're not leaving tonight.
No.
You th-
Shhhhhhhh.  They drive in silence for several moments. The reassuring RUMBLE of the ENGINE. The WHIZZ of the TIRES on the blacktop. Outside, the long, far, dark. The two of them together.
Stop the truck.
Here?
Now.
Sure. He pulls the vehicle to the side of the road. He turns to her. Her icy blue eyes radiating heat. His heart coming out of his chest.
So...
Something I want to show you. Her door is all at once open. She is out of the truck. He kills the engine and jumps onto the hard ground.

Mae stands alone. A black silhouette against a blacker horizon. A sky stretching high above her head. Stars like from a shotgun blast. He comes toward her. The WIND whips the clothes around her soft, sultry form. Her eyes shining in the night.
What did you want to show me?
The night.
What about it?
It's dark.
Noticed.
It's also bright. It'll blind you.
I can't see.
Listen.
I'm listening.
Do y'hear?
Don't hear nothin'.
Listen again. Do ya hear?
what?
The night. It's deafening.
Hold your ears.
Listen hard. They are close. Face to face. His lips lowering to hers. Her lips moist. Caleb tries to kiss her. Mae moves off. He follows.
Haven't met many girls like you.
You haven't met any girls like me.

Maybe not. He has a loose, game grin on his face as he walks after t girl. She walks with an easy, lazy gait. Plucking a cat's tail from the field. Putting it between her teeth. A sweet smile beneath the pale moonlight. Mae casts a glance over her shoulder at the smitten boy b her.
Look up.
Stars.
See that one?
First one I laid eyes on.

The light you just saw took a billion whole years to get from that star down here to earth... The light that's leaving that star right now, it'll be here a billion years from now... She spins on her heel. Fixes his face in her own.
Want to know why you never met a girl like me before?
Yeah. She casts a glance up at the stars.
...I'll be around to see that light when it comes down to earth a billion years from now.  10
Sounds like fun.
It is.
I'd like to be there, too.
Maybe.
How?
who knows? She turns and heads back toward the Ford Pickup. He catches her stride.
Sure haven't met anyone like you before.
Sure haven't. They climb in. They take off. The night is just as dark as it was before. Maybe darker.
Caleb leans back in his seat, raising his right arm to Ma shoulder. Extending his fingers, he ruffles her hair.
In any hurry to get home? The truck drives on. Mae lifts thoses shimmering eyes to his face.
I never hurry. Caleb smiles and shakes his head, somehow now believing.

...You want to listen to the radio?  11 His fingers twirl a ribbon of her hair. He gives the knob a flick. The speakers vibrate. The Pickup speeds on into the night. The lonesome road stretching into the horizon. The RADIO playing.
The road forks. The truck veers to the right.
Mae turns to Caleb. The paleness of her skin almost luminescent.
Where're we going? Caleb's eyes sparkle.
You'll see.
I don't like surprises.
You'll like this one.
What is it?
Not what.
who?
You'll see.
I'm not sure I'm going to like this. A smile in her eyes.
I'm sure.  12
The Pickup barrels around a junction of the highway. Funneling a cloud of dust onto a narrow dirt road. RATTLING a broken down mailbox sitting atop a short post. The farm sleeping still and dark.
Caleb steers past the house. Braking in a shower of dust in front of the pasture behin barn. He kills the engine.
We're here.
Where's here?
C'mon. He swings the door open.
Caleb races around the truck, cracking open Mae's door. He extends his hand as she hops out.
Close your eyes, take hold of my hand. You're going to meet my best friend. She tugs his hand.
I don't want to be with other people. I want to be with you tonight. He gives her hand a gentle pull.
It's not a person. Close your eyes. She does. Letting herself be led out of the vehicle. He leads her blind back through a maze of fences out in t pasture.  13
In its pen, DIESEL, a massive black quarterhorse pricks u ears. Turning wide, dark eyes on Caleb and Mae. Caleb gets behind Mae and puts his hand on her shoulder.

Now I don't want you opening your eyes. He puts his other hand over her eyes. A big smile on his face as he edges her forward. Suddenly the horse backs so abruptly it almost trips. Eyes wild with fear. The two people just stand there. The farmboy pulls his hand away from the girl's eyes. He walks up to the pen.
Diesel, what the hell is wrong with you? Mae opens her eyes.
Horses don't like me. Caleb takes a rope and slings it over Diesel's head.
Why not?
They just don't.
Come on boy. He gives the rope a tug. Diesel rears back, lifting his chest, front hooves pawing air.

He's just acting up. He'll like you. Just watch. He vaults the fence. Diesel shies. Caleb tries to shush it. The horse shakes its head back and forth, scared out of i skin.  14 Bewildered, the farmboy lifts the rope over its head. The horse pivots on its back feet, tearing off. Caleb heads back toward Mae. Climbing back over the fence and standing beside her. Her watching him with uncannily even eyes. Smiling elusively to herself, she turns her back to him. Moving off with an easy gait past the other pens. Inside the fences, there is a SCURRYING of animals. A sudden RUSTLING in the nearby tundra of the prairie. Caleb scans the landscape, sets his eyes on Mae, then sha head and shrugs. Mae is sauntering away, her back to him, running her fing along the fence posts. The farmboy swings the lasso lariet style over his head. Letting the loop fall over the girl's shoulders. She looks over her shoulder at him. Her eyes cool. He smiles. Starts reeling her in. She backs. A smile slipping across her face.
You're pretty strong. He gives the rope another tug. Moving her closer. The moon shines bright and high overhead.
Stronger than you.

Show me. She pulls back. Pulling him to her. He gives a gentle tug. She comes within reach. Then twists back. A game of give and take. He comes forward. Gathering up the rope in his hands. Their eyes wedded. She is just in front of him now. He gives one last tug on the line. Drawing her in. His face drifting toward hers. Letting his lips brush over hers and stops. Her eyes close. His hands fold around her back. A cloud passes over the moon.  15 A shadow crosses their faces. Her soft, moist lips slide over his mouth. Nuzzling down the side of his neck. He lifts closed eyes to the sky. Her breath warm on his skin. His skin trembling with the touch. Her lips start to draw back. She jerks her head back, struggling with her instinct. Lifting her arms, yanking the rope off her shoulders.
What's wrong? Mae hugs her arms. Her eyes holding his. Time standing still.
Horizon lightening. Just a tad.
A Rooster throws back its combed head and COCK-A-DOODLE-D
Mae's ears perk at the rooster crow. Her icy blue eyes skate up to the sky. Her face focuses on Caleb's in alarm.
What time is it? Caleb shrugs his shoulders.
What time you gotta be home?
Before dawn.
Dawn's a ways off. Mae spins on her heel. Heads off for the truck.
Take me home, Caleb.  16
Huh? He trots after her. Lays a hand on her shoulder. Stopping her movement. Turning her around. Her eyes blaze into his face.
What's the rush, Mae?

I have to go. She breaks free. Keeps walking. Reaching the truck, she opens her door. His eyes search hers as she climbs into the seat. Reading nothing. He closes her door. Resting his elbows on the open windowframe. He starts to speak, she cuts him off.
Hurry, Caleb. Hurry. He gazes into those eyes for a fleeting moment, then move around to the driver's side and swings onto the seat.
Caleb puts his hand on the keys in the ignition. Giving her a good, hard look.
I don't know what's goin' on, Mae. She flits a peek out the window.
The truck sits unshielded beneath the big sky becoming li grey.
Mae shoots a scared glance at Caleb.
Let's go.  17
We're going. The farmboy TURNS over the ENGINE. Upset, he shoves the stick into gear. Swinging the truck around. Stepping on the gas, he takes them out of there.
Hope I didn't forget my manners or nothin'.
That's not it. She casts a glance up out the windshield.
Move.
Yes, Ma'am. His brow furrows in confusion. He swings the steering wheel hand over hand. Driving out onto the road.
The truck burns down the tarmac toward the brightening ho
Caleb keeps his hands on the wheel. Staring straight out the windshield. Hurt. Mae sits rigidly beside him. Perspiration like dew drops on her porcelain skin. Real fear in her eyes.
Faster.
I got her floored.
It's only a few more miles.
Might even get there, you never know.  18
I didn't notice the time.
What's got you so worried? Mae's eyes never leave the windshield. She answers him with silence.
C'mon, what is it? Your old man gonna whip your butt or somethin'? I'll tell him the car broke down.
Just get me home.
Maybe I will... He puts his foot on the brake. A playful gleam in his eye.
The truck pulls to a halt. Sunrise a matter of moments.
Caleb yanks the keys out the ignition. Sticks them down his shirt. Sits back and crosses his arms.

...But you have to kiss me first. Anxiety squirms her pretty face. She reaches over and tries to pull the keys from inside h shirt. Her hands all over his chest. He grabs her by the wrist. Tugs her to him. Grinning boyishly ear to ear.

You got the idea. She struggles. He kisses her full on the lips. Mae shuts her eyes. Surrendering to something spasming inside her.  19 Her mouth moves to his neck. Her lips pull back. Her teeth fasten onto his neck. Caleb cries out. Tries to push her off. She holds him firm by the shoulders in an iron grip. Tears explode out of her eyes. She rips her blood moistened lips from his neck. Shearing herself away from him. Plunging out the door of the truck. Headfirst. Caleb remains in the seat. Rubbing his throat. Fingering the pinprick of a wound. Surprised and astonished, he jumps out of the parked vehi Chasing after the panic-stricken girl scrambling away.

The girl is running as fast as her feet will carry her. Her eyes wide and wild. A dribble of blood dappling her white lips. The farmboy is racing after her. She moves with a speed that is leaving him rapidly in her The sky is becoming very bright indeed. Mae stops in her tracks and squints ahead. Up the road, fast approaching. A ballooning cloud of dust. A low to the ground funnel of dirt. Caleb watches as the girl runs toward it, flagging her ar A vehicle inside the little twister SLAMS on its BRAKES. Mae jumps inside the dirty haze. The dust cloud swerves in a SCREECHING TIRE arc on the ro speeding back up the road. The sun about to crack the edge of the world. A faint wreath of smoke in the air where the girl last st Caleb slows to a sprint. Then a walk. He stops and stands. Watching the dust disintigrate up the road. He scratches his head. Touches the strange wound on his throat. He regards the red wetness on his fingers.
Some kiss. He shrugs and hikes back to his truck. Hops into the cab.  20
Caleb turns the keys in the ignition. WHINNNEEEEE. WHINNNNNNNNEEEE. WHINNEEEEE. He checks out the gas gauge. Empty. He punches the dashboard.
Shit. He jumps out of the truck.
Caleb crosses the blacktop. Leaving the truck on the side of the road. Hiking into the dry fields. His house a small speck on the field far away. He heads toward it. The sun near up.

LOY and SARAH COLTON have come outside to start their day The father is a man in his middle years, with weathered s white hair on a face and body worn by a life on the land. He is holding his six year old daughter in his arms. Golden hair on a pretty, pug nosed face. Loy is holding a cup of coffee. Sippng it as he looks out on the morning lands with his b girl. Sky brightening.

The edge of the world turns white. Caleb clomps through the field. Squinting ahead to see the small shape of the farmhouse, The specks of two people standing out front. Home a half mile away. The boy trudges toward it. The world brightening around him. He hugs himself. The light making his skin sore. The sun crests the rim of the planet. Spreading an infinite wall of light across the big countr A wave of sharp sunlight splashing over the running boy. He lets out a cry of pain.  21
Loy Colton squints out into the lands. Sees the stick figure way out there. Sarah stretches her teeny arm and points. Jumps up and down.
Lookit, Daddy. Caleb.
Hey, Caleb! The father waves at his son. The sister stands by his side. The two of them framed picture pretty in front of the hou

Caleb squirms in agony. Staggering across the fields. Blisters and burn marks scorching on his skin. The sun roasting his flesh. Searing his face and hair. He runs drunkenly. His arms stretched out. His hands reaching for the two of his family members. And his house. Like a pastoral postcard of home a quarter of a mile away Smoke rises from his fingers. His skin stinging. His whole body burning up in the abruptly scarifying ligh day. He screams his lungs out. His arms covering his face. Sizzling.
Loy stops waving. His face falls. Sarah snags his shirt sleeve. Alarmed.
Is something wrong with Caleb?
I'm not sure. They squint into the distance. Past the stumbling, smoking stick figure of Caleb.  22 Just past him. Dust rising.

Tears stream down Caleb's cheeks. His smouldering, raw hands outstretched. Snatching, clenching for the too far figures of his fathe his sister. Fighting his way past the warring wall of the sun. His feet becoming harder and harder to move. Fighting a losing battle against the agonizing scorch of daylight. The SOUND of an AUTOMOTIVE ENGINE behind him. He looks desperately over his shoulder. A balloon of dirt. A pale, ghostly cream colored Winnegabo is bearing down o Almost upon him. He knows it is useless to resist. He surrenders, his eyes rolling up into their sockets. His legs giving out from under him. Knees buckling. The recreational vehicle lumbers by. It's side door swinging open. Three sets of hands clamping around Caleb's limp body as drops. Heaving the door shut. Speeding off.

Loy and Sarach are thunderstruck. They see the Winnebago hang a sharp right in an explosion dirt. Greyhounding it for the strip of two-lane blacktop a quar a mile away. Caleb being stolen away within.
Caleb!

Sarah, you stay here. Loy charges as fast as his aging feet will carry him acro farm. Around the side of the barn. Screeching to a halt in front of a Chevy Pickup. The Truck is up on a jack, its tire off. The father is white in the face. Sarah is standing beside him with her eyes as big as sauc Watching the thin trail of dust disappear down the road.  23 The father picks up his daughter. She hugs him, sobbing. A steeliness appears behind his eyes as he looks out at t road. The two of them stand small and alone on the farm. Surrounded by the huge Oklahoma landscape.

The sun is a twisted green ball through the glass windshi It's deadly rays leaking inside. Caleb twists a groggy face upward, lifting his lids. To see the sharp bladed rowel of a shining silver spur st against his throat. It is connected to a boot. Attached to a steamshovel of a leg in black jeans. Part of the body of a stapping sinewy man with a mean, sk face and eyes like dead meat. SEVEREN VAN SICKLE.
Howdy . He puts pressure on the spur, pricking flesh.

...I'm gonna separate your head from yer shoulders. Hope ya don't mindnone. Caleb gags. A snarl from somebody beneath a blanket behind the wheel. Severen grunts and reluctantly looses the pressure on the bit. Mae heaves a blanket over Caleb who isn't moving a single solitary muscle. His eyes jump to the driver, who is speeding the Winnebag flat-out 100. JESSE HOOKER's head swivels over his shoulder, deeply hoo a blanket and eyes covered by very black welding glasses. A guantly handsome man with a face like the flip side of nickel and a long mane of hair the color of burnished pew
You fucked us up but good, Mae.
It was kinda an accident.
This was sloppy, Mae, real sloppy.  24 Severen indents the sharp rowel of the spur in Caleb's th The farmboy is scared beyond belief.
Let me do it, Jesse, let me tap dance on it, woncha Jess? It'll be so good.

Do it fast. In the seat beside Jesse, another head rises. The blanket parting to reveal a face to put a country boy place. A head of metallic blonde hair over chiseled features as marble. Her full, bloodless lips widen in a silky smile. Her eyes, an intoxicating lethal lure. DIAMONDBACK's studded denim and fringe jacket glints like eyes in the dark. She whips out her wrist and a pearl handled blade pops in hand. She readies to use it.
Let the good times roll. Mae grabs her arm.

No!!! Caleb's eyes are wide and wild. Severen draws his leg back, poising his spur. The Winnebago hurtles at hi-speed. The farmboy tries to make a move. CLINK. CHINK. Handcuffs are thrown about his wrist and a bolt on the do He's caught tight. His eyes find a .38 special aimed point blank in his face Held in a two hand grip by a seven year old boy. Crouched in a corner. A tiny face pinched, hair clipped in a crewcut. His clothes probably procured at the Salvation Army. HOMER. He eases back the hammer. Snaps his eyes possessively to Mae.
Him?  25
No! Spur. Knife. Handcuff. .38. Nuts.

head_text.subj: WHAT THE FUCK IS GOING ON

text: Ain't what's goin' on, son. It's what's coming off. Your face. Clean off. Severen's face splits with a smile like a cut neck. Slashing out with his spur for Caleb's throat to lay it w open. Mae suddenly puts her face in front of the farmboy's. The Savage One stops his spur an inch from her pretty pal throat. She holds his gaze.
Might as well kill me.
How you figure that? Mae yanks Caleb's head aside, displaying the red ringed t marks in his neck.
He's been bit but he ain't been bled. That sinks in.
...He's turned by now.
Aw shit, Jess. If he's turned...

...He comes with us. Caleb is perfectly still. His eyes the only part of his body that moves. Back and forth, back and forth. Nobody talks.  26 Nobody moves. Black nervous looks all around. The vehicle drives on.
The pale Winnebago takes a sharp right and grinds to a st within the darkened innards of a derelict, deserted garag A lightless chamber.

Jesse and Diamondback pop back the front seats into almos horizontal positions. Ready themselves for sleep. Severen unhinges the bunks on the walls of the van. He climbs into the top, WHIZZING a spur in Caleb's direct Homer shoves up into the one beneath. Casting a grim eye on the farmboy as he pulls the blanket over his head. Mae rests a hand gently on the boy's shoulder. He gazes up into her eyes. Suddenly very tired. Heavily weighted but somehow floating at the same time. He fights to keep his eyes open. They shut. Mae covers both their bodies with the blanket. Sleep steals her too.

Sun burning hot and bright on a sign reading, "Loy Colton Veterinarian." A POLICE CAR sitting in front of the farmhouse. Down in the field Loy cradles Sarah in his arms and gazes straight into SHERIFF EAKERS face. The Sheriff tucks a couple of thumbs in the belt around h landslide girth. Tilting an eye.

Kidnapped..? C'mon, Loy, your boy's eighteen. Might be he figured to take himself some time on his own. I see it all the day. Sarah sniffles. Loy looks down to the ground and the fresh tire marks in earth. Shaking his head. Eakers glances down at the marks dismissively. Shifting his weight from one foot to the other.  27
By the way, Doc, you mind taking a look at my mare? She's all swole up on her back, needs a shot maybe. Loy looks at his watch in annoyance. Then stabs the ground with the toe of his boot.

See these tire marks? That was four hours and nine minutes ago. Meanin' that if they're out there on the highway keepin' at a steady 55 that puts 'em clear into the next state by now. I wanna know what you boys are doin' about that? Sarah digs her face into her stern father's jacket. The Sheriff sighs. The three of them very small on the very big stretch of l
The sun settles on the decrepit shell of a gas station of lonesome road. The sky dims. The night begins.

Caleb's eyes blink open. He keeps them almost closed. Playing dead. He fingers his burn wounds. They are barely there. Nearly healed. The five silhouettes of the rest in the dashboard lights. Huddling. Low voices. He listens close.
...I'1l look after him.
You can't Mae! I turned you! I taught you!
I turned him. I'm teachin' him.  28
Risky as shit, Jess. He fucks up, it's our ass.
If it's our ass, Mae, it's your ass.
Well... The glint of Jesse's eyes passing around the others.

...You want to call it a week? Mae holds her breath. Severen spits tobacco. Homer keeps opening and closing the hammer of the gun. Diamondback fingers the rhinestone studs of her frayed bl denim jacket. Jesse clicks his teeth. His eyes snap to Diamondback. She nods.
...Then it's decided. A week to see if we can call him one of us. Caleb blinks. Severen catches it.

Cut the shit. I know you're awake. I can smell it. All eyes turn to him. Eyes that can see in the dark. Caleb opens his eyes. Severen gets to his feet. Stands over him. Whips out a straightrazer. The farmboy's stomach tightens. Severen spits on his palm. Smears the saliva over his rough hewn face. Starts shaving himself with the open blade, slicing whisk
...Amazin' how fast they get dull. The Savage One sticks out his hand. Yanks the farmboy to his feet.  29 Homer unlatches his handcuff. Caleb rubs his wrist.

head_text.subj: IF I'M SLEEPING SLAP ME CAUSE I WANNA

text: Guess what?

I'm Jesse Hooker. I believe you've met Mae. Caleb hears a sound which makes him turn his head fast. ZZ2Z2ZZZ222ZZZ722zzzzZaaaaawww . AZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZAAAAWWWWWWWZZZZZ .. Severen FILING his teeth with a metal tool. Sharpening them. Winking at the farmboy.

Severen Van Sickle's the name. Diamondback flexes her wrist. Shooting her pearl handled blade out of her cuff and into hand. She flexes her wrist. The blade drops back in her jacket. She flexes her wrist again. Blade in hand.
Diamondback. Caleb is looking at her. A teeny hand grabs him by the nuts. Clenches hard. He groans. Falls to his knees. Eye level with Homer. Who puts his little face fiercely against Caleb's.

I'm Homer. That's H-O-M-E-R. Mispronounce it once and I wouldn't want to be you.  30 Mae takes the stunned, speechless Caleb and sits him down seat in the back. He starts to say something. She puts her finger to his lip. The Silvered One turns over the ignition.
The Winnebago rides out of the gutted garage.
The Winnebago slows to a stop in front of the lot.
Severen moves silently through the rows of vehicles in th safety of shadow with a well practised ease.
The Winnebago streaks through the night. A light green TRAVELALL on its tail. Small towns come and go. Giving way to dust covered plains stretching to the horiz
The Winnebago has been torched. It is a smouldering skeleton of flickering flames. The red taillights of the Travelall racing toward the roa Shrinking from view.
The Travelall speeds across the state line.
The Travelall weaves through the streets of the small cit

The Travelall pulls into the parking structure. Zooming through the cement catacombs. Swerving into a parking spot. Shutting its engine. All doors pop open. They all climb out. And stretch their legs. Jesse turns a grey eye on the farmboy. A faint grin wrinkles across that epic face. Caleb swallows.  31 Mae comes up beside him. Weaving her fingers through his hand. The farmboy watches as the others take off into the night Each heading in separate directions.
Caleb and Mae walk along the empty, lonely street beneath yellowish glow of the mercury vapor light. City lights glisten up ahead.
Where're we going?
I'll show you.
Where?
There. She nods toward the city in front of her.
Why?
I'll show you. His eyes dim. A nausea welling up inside him.
I don't feel too well.

I know. He looks at her. Probing inside those ice blue eyes. Then down at himself. The burns on his arms healed. His clothes singed. Another wave of nausea. It makes him want to scream. He stops in his tracks.  32
Look, Mae, you got to understand. I'm gettin' outa here. I'm going to the nearest bus station and takin' the next one back home. He takes a step toward the girl. Holding her by the shoulders.
I know you tried to help me. But I got to get home. Touching a finger to her cheek. He turns his back. Taking off down the street. A knowing passes behind the girl's eye.
Caleb, you won't get very far. From halfway down the street he looks back. Hurt, anger and fear streaking his face.
We'll see.
You know where I'll be.
Be seeing you. Quietly.
Before long. Caleb lifts a hand in a slight wave. Casting a last look at the girl. And her melting gaze. Then he is gone. The night moves on. Mae stands still.
The depot in the middle of nowhere on the empty streets o small midwestern town. Caleb shambles along the sidewalk toward it. Pushing through the double glass doors.  33
The farmboy walks up to the ticket counter. The TICKETER doesn't give him a second glance.
Um, excuse me... The man turns, not eyeing the worse for wear boy any diff than he would any of the other wierdos up and around at t time.
...I'd like to know if you got any buses going through Fix, Oklahoma round about now? The Ticketer just stares.
Where the hell is Fix?
Well, nearest city is Lawton. The man nods.
Gate 12. Fifteen minutes. 14 dollars. Caleb opens his wallet and counts.
I got 11 dollars. The Ticketer pulls the ticket back, bored.
I got a bus ticket for 14.
I gotta get home. Gimme a break man.
You're three bucks shy.

How ‘bout it. The farmboy exhales as the salesperson goes back to watch portable television.  34 His shoulders slumped, Caleb walks past the rows of plast seats with the pay televisions on the armrests. Almost all empty. He spies a man in a rumpled suit sitting across the room. Looking at him laconically. The boy goes over.
Scuse me, Sir... The man looks up.
...I'm trying to get home and I'm three dollars short for the ticket. I was wondering if you had-
I have this. He reaches into his jacket for his wallet. Pulls it out.
Thanks. The wallet is flipped open. A badge in it. The PLAINCLOTHES COP puts his hand on the farmboy's shoul The hand has a bandage. The bandage has blood on it. Fresh.
Come this way, please.
What's the problem?
You.
The boy is walked into the shadowy locker area by the Plainclothes Police Officer.
You're not lookin' too good, kid.
I'm not feeling too good.  35
What're you on?
You wouldn't believe me if I told you.

Let me see your eyes. He puts his hand on Caleb's face. Squints into the boy's eyes. Which are perfectly clear. The blood on the small bandage near Caleb's nose. Nostrils flare. His nausea clearing for an instant. The cop fingers the dark stain on the collar of the farmb jacket.
You got blood on you. Caleb turns his neck to the man. Exposing the small puncture wound.
I got cut... The sickness returning. The farmboy close to tears. The cop looks him in the eyes with some compassion.
...I only have 11 dollars and I need three more or I'm never gonna be able to get back home. The policeman thinks for a moment. Then takes out his wallet. Gives the boy three dollars.
Get home an' be a good boy. Caleb smiles a bright boyish smile. The plainclothes cop pats him on the shoulder. The farmboy moves off.
The long silvery bus streaks down the highway. A half moon watches from way on high.  36

Caleb is curled up in the backseat. Buckled in pain. His face smeared with sweat. Clenching his stomach. His veins and arteries screaming out for sustenance. His eyes peer over the edge of the window sill. He sees the parking structure pass by. Jumping to his feet, he rushes down the aisle. Screeching to a sneakered halt behind the Bus Driver.
Stop the bus! I gotta get off! The Bus Driver lifts his face to the sweat soaked farmboy
You get off, you're left. The pain in Caleb's eyes needs no words. The driver downgrades as he swings over to the curb.

location: STREETS ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF HOPE, KANSAS

text: The huge, lumbering vehicle grinds to a stop on the empty street. The doors heave open. Caleb climbs down the steps in a crouch. The Bus Driver shakes his head as the doors fold closed. In a cloud of exhaust, the vehicle lurches away. Caleb grabs onto the lamppost for support. He swings his dimming eyes around. Focusing on the parking structure in the near distance.

Caleb staggers out of the stairwell. Stumbling toward the light green Travelall. Sitting on the bumper, in bare feet, is Mae. A soft smile crosses his face. Caleb stops in front of her. Losing his balance. Weakening.
I'm dying.

You're just in time.  37 In the shadow of the overhand Mae rises to her feet befor Caleb. Her ice blue eyes fix on his. She lifts her hand to her mouth. Turning a glistening white wrist to her lips. And sinks her teeth into the skin.
Wwha- -? The red liquid runs down her arm as she raises the wrist Caleb's mouth. Shutting out his voice. Fastening her skin to his face.

Drink. The aroma filling his nostrils. Giving him strength. The strength giving him pleasure. Seizing him. Like two arms, kidnapping his senses. As his lips look on the gaping wound of her wrist and her begins to fill his veins. He clutches her with both hands, rolling the fabric of he blouse into his fists. Hearing the pounding rhythm of her heart. BABUM. . .BABUM. . .BABUMBABUMBABUMBABUMBABUMBABUMBABUM. Getting faster. A kind of frenzy passing behind his eyes. The blood in his own veins running hot. Stimulated. Stirred.
I asked you to listen to the night... now listen to me.

The roaring in his ears. Smashing her into him. Draining her. Furiously. The blood running like fire inside him. Washing over him in waves of heat. Head reeling. Body spasming. His own heart finding its way to his ears. BABUMBABUMBABUM. . . BABUMBABUM. . .BABUMBABUMBABUMBABUM. Both hearts now in syncopated rhythm.  38 A beating drum. Growing louder and louder. It's DEAFENING. The SOUND about to shatter his system. Mae beginning to pull back. He yanks her tighter. She summons the last of her strength. And rips herself free. Caleb's mouth drips with the dark, red liquid. Replenished. Restored. Remade. Caleb's face flushes and his eyes shine with unhealthy he Breathing hard. Panting. The new found strength swirling through his body. He reaches for the girl. She pushes his hands away gently. Then presses the wound closed on her wrist. Her eyes soft and knowing. Walking forward, to the edge of the parking structure. Looking out. Caleb pulls himself together. A control returning. Standing beside the girl with a kind of gratitude in his She points. Gazing out upon the city on one side and wide expanse of flatlands on the other. All beneath a velvety cloak of blackness.

Look... the night. Caleb blinks. Eyes bright. Feeling fine. Not sure of what to make of it. He squints around him. Never has the night looked as it does. He stares spellbound. A fine layer of lunar luminescence falls from the sky. The city shimmering as never before. The very electrical pulse visible as it travels through t air. He blinks. Turning toward the fields. He can see Owls in the air many miles away. Coyotes on the run across the barren tundra impossibly fa Fieldmice scuttle. Rabbits skiddadle. Racoons clamber across the brushy flatlands.  39 Caleb whirls around and around. Giggling. Then laughing. Unable to help himself. In love with the newness of the night. He stops.

Now hear it.... His head flicks back to the city. Suddenly, VIBRATING with SOUND. CAR HORNS. ELECTRICITY TRAVELING ACROSS WIRES. TICKING OF STREET LIGHTS. HISSING OF GAS LINES. He revolves his head. To the fields. He shuts his eyes. Opens his ears. A SYMPHONY of NIGHT SOUNDS sweep in on him.
Come on. She leaps over the small barrier of the parking structure runs out into the farmlands. Caleb on her heels.

Mae and Caleb running deep into the fields. Running like never before. Limbs flying effortlessly, galloping like the wind, almos airborne, covering miles in a matter of minutes. Caleb listening. A RUSH of BREEZES and WINDS whipping along the plains. The WALL of INSECTS in the AIR. The SCUTTLING of small animal FEET on the DIRT. The BRUSH of BUSHES swaying in the BREEZE. The CRY of COYOTES. Then again. COYOTES CRY. CRY. CRY. CRY. Caleb throws his head back. Cracks a grin. He lets out a YIPPING CRY himself. Mae's face widens in a smile. Throwing her head back. Letting out a trilling CRY.  40 The COYOTES yell back. Caleb and Mae see them in a pack, scampering across the l They run after them. CRYING out, loud as their lungs will allow. A far off TRAIN WHISTLE. The shadow of a big Freight Train on the horizon. The boy and girl's legs propelling them forward with fier speed. Like two steel springs. Their faces flushed with emotion as they catch up with th COYOTES on the run. The strong, tan canines regard their new escorts as a kin spirit. Flashing their dark eyes at them in scraggy acknowledgeme YIPPING at them. Caleb and Mae YIP back. Barreling across the badlands with the running Coyotes. The padding paws. The cowboy boots slapping the ground. Then suddenly catching up with the big Freight Train. The boy and girl running side by side with the double eng locomotive. The strange strength powering their limbs to stay abreast The lowered, brown maned wolfish heads at their heels. The Coyotes YIPPING. The train WHISTLE BLOWING. Caleb and Mae's faces bright and hot blooded.
Daylight twinkles.

Loy Colton awakens at the top of his lungs. Jackknifing up in bed. He puts his face in his hands. Cries quietly. He peers out the window at the first traces of sunlight t the curtains. He looks like he has slept poorly. Loy regards the shape of a small body, an indentation on mattress. His daughter was sleeping beside him, but now she's gone. His brow furrows.
Sarah? Nowhere to be seen. The father gets out of bed.  41 He has been sleeping in his jeans and shirt. Rumpled and worse for wear, he goes out the door.
Loy walks down the hall in the morning light. He knows where she is.

The father quietly pushes open the door. Peeks in. Little Sarah asleep on her big brother's bed. Hugging onto his beat up cowboy hat. Loy blinks away a tear. He turns his back and starts to go out. A small voice stops him.
Good mornin', Daddy. He comes over to her.
Mornin', Baby. He puts his hand on her tiny hand holding the Stetson.
You sleep some?
I sleep some. You sleep little?
Little. Bad dreams.
Me too. She meets his eyes.
...He needs us. Loy takes Sarah's hand.
I know. They look at each other.  42
The Pickup truck is spewing a cloud of dust. Off into the distance.

A hole in the wall. A small computer bank on the desk by the telephone. A few wanted posters and postal warrants on the board. Sheriff Eakers shakes his head as he stabs a cigarette ou ash tray full of butts. He lifts tired eyes to Loy Colton, sitting across the des Sarah in her father's lap.

It's not much, Loy, but Highway Patrol found what might be your Winnebago. Left in some field and torched. Nobody was inside. Probably switched cars. Could be your boy's fallen in with some trouble. Loy speaks in a voice just below his breath.
What're your boys doing about it?
All we can.
That's not enough.
This is pretty commonplace stuff, Loy. Your boy is classified as a runaway. Sarah pipes up, red in the face.
You don't care about Caleb.
That's not true, honey.

Don't call me honey. We don't need you police or nothing. Caleb don't need you neither. He needs us.  43 The little girl puts her hands on the table. Leaning over to put her face by the Sheriff's, who is inc to lean back a bit.
We're gonna go an' get him ourselves. The Sheriff gets up out of his seat. He walks over to the water cooler. Pours himself a cup. Chuckling to himself. His back to them.
Loy, you just have to bear with us for a bit. He turns around with a sip of water. The chair Loy and Sarah were sitting in. It's empty. He hurries to the door.
The brown Chevy Pickup is a speck disintegrating in the distance.
The Pickup is down the road like a bolt of lightning.
Loy is behind the wheel. His eyes riveted to the road. He puts an arm around Sarah. Brings her to him. Hugs her close. She looks up at him.
We're going to get our Caleb back Sarah.
I know we will. She hugs her father's arm. He ruffles her hair. Then reaches under the seat.  44
Loy double checks with his fingers that the .38 Special i securely taped to the bottom of his seat.

The Pickup passes beneath an overhead sign. Denoting the Interstate and two turn offs. One heading North to Kansas. The other heading South to Texas. The Pickup bears South. The sun lifting high in the sky.
Operator, I'd like to reverse charges on a long distance call to Oklahoma, please...
The night drops. A swelling moon in the rise of the middle of a blackening Caleb lifts a receiver to his ear and dials.
That's (405) 826-7473. Could you make that to Loy Colton from his son, please, Ma'am?... He waits while he is connected. Waits. Waits. Waits. In vain. His face falls very far.
Thanks, operator. He hangs up. Walks away with his head hung low.

A long, two lane stretch of blacktop into infinity. Broken white lines beneath the black void of the starless Caleb storms along the roadside. The Texaco Truckstop receding behind him. His tortured, conflicting emotions tearing him apart at t seams. He shuts his eyes.  45 Puts his hands on his ears. Screams. His lungs out. Hastening as fast as he can along the empty night road. A pair of headlights brighten on him. A truck THUNDERS past. The AFTERBLOW sweeping his clothes. It's passing headlights revealing the figure of a girl hu after him. Mae rushes up the side of the road. Keeping pace with the anxiety-ridden boy. It is just the two of them way below the roof of the nigh
I wanted to go home, too. Mae stops and stands. Caleb doesn't walk much further. He turns to face her.
I called, there was no one there. I just wanted to call and tell them I was alright. He almost laughs or cries.
Am I alright? I don't know. I'm scared. Mae comes toward him.
So was I. But don't be... Feel it. Feel what's in you. He meets her eyes. Eyes like fire in the night.
That's what scares me. She puts her hands softly on his shoulders.
It'll take time. But you're in my hands, you'll be fine. He looks at those hands, then into that face.  46
What are we gonna do?
Anything we want. She unveils her pearly whites in a sweet smile full of pr

To the end of time. His eyes travel up to the stars. Hers follow his gaze. Their eyes meet in a head on collision. Lips coming together. A truck RAGES past. AFTERBLOW whippping up their clothes and hair. Headlights exploding over them. Heat of the moment. The truck's taillights fade. They are alone in the big dark wide open spaces. Their lips part.
You have to learn to kill.
I don't want to kill.
You want to die?
I ain't no killer.
Don't think of it as killing. Don't think at all. Use your instinct. A Car passes. Headlights flare.

Bright headlight beams sweep off the side of the road. A MIDDLE-AGED MAN throws his door wide, leaping out. Rushing over to the crumpled little form of Homer, lying road. He bends down to see how injured he is.  47

...It's just something you do, night after night. It's only evera question of how... Homer's eyes blink open. He throws his incredibly strong little arms around the ma shoulders. Pinning him while he sinks his teeth into the startled passerby's neck. The headlights of the car silhouetting them. Homer has a bicycle laying on the ground nearby. The tires still spinning.
Caleb and Mae walking along the shoulder of the road.
Instinct? His soft brown eyes searching hers. That clear ice blue cutting deep into him.
Instinct.

A pair of drifting, distant headlights pin Severen standi the side of the road with his thumb extended. The crisp white shirt over his long, lean muscles, button to his throat, a string tie with a turquoise clasp at the collar. An inviting grin on his face. He runs a palm over his hair to smooth it back. His black eyes gleam. The headlights grow bright and flood his face. His grin widens. As he looks in through the windshield of an approaching d Black Pickup. Severen nods. The Pickup slows. Kicking up dirt and gravel as it slams into the shoulder on ramp.
It takes time.
That we got.  48 Severen cracks open the door of the Pickup.
Never know, might even get to like it.

"Evenin'. The two blonde, curly haired LADIES smile out at him with adventure in their eyes. The one in the passenger seat slides next to the driver. Her small, whispery voice floats out to the stranger on t road.
Evenin'.
Severen swings onto the smooth plastic upholstery. Slams the door shut. Winds a long arm around the top of the seat He turns a shining smile to his new found friends.
It would be my pleasure and honor to invite you two, sweet, lovely ladies for a drink.
The dusty Pickup skates out onto the tarmac. A hot WIND blows.
Jesse gazes out the windshield with cool, even eyes. Diamondback at his side. Her platinum hair gleaming in the glow of the dashboard l Equally transfixed by the road rolling under the wheels.
The night, Mae. I can't take my eyes off it.
You can drown in it.
Iam. I can taste it. It's... It's making me shaky.  49
That's because you have to---
--Kill.
The night has its price. The Silvered One gives a glance to the Pale One.
I believe this is where I had that flat tire. You pulled over.
There you stood by the side of that road, 'n I 'just knew you were trouble.
You was right.
How many years ago was that?
Disremember, huh? Don't remember the date of the night, neither, do you? A sparkle in her eye.
Jesse. The Silvered One keeps his eyes on the road, but lets go little smile. She lays her head against his shoulder. They drive on.
Two white cones of light from the approaching U-Haul Truc A lone HITCHHIKER suddenly illuminated.

Jesse gives a glance to Diamondback. He slows the vehicle. The Semi-Truck comes to a stop beside the Hitchhiker. A tall, thin, stringy haired boy with half a beard and a bruised face. He waves a ragged smile into the cab.  50
Whichever way you headin'. I'd "preciate a lift. Diamondback cracks open the rear door.
Climb in. He jumps inside. CLICK. To the left of Jesse's ear. As a pair of eyes bore down the barrel of a shotgun level Jesse's face. A HIGHWAYMAN behind the trigger.

Turn off the car. Jesse looks into his face. A stubby grin widens across broken teeth. CLICK. The Hitchhiker in the back seat takes the safety off a Co Python. Pressing the cold metal nose against the nape of Diamondb neck.
Hey, mister. My pal here told you to turn off the car. Jesse looks calmly over his shoulder. Switches off the ignition.

Now, you mind if I dance with your wife here? She's a real looker, this one. He winds the nose of his gun up Diamondback's neck and in soft pale hair. Jesse gazes over his shoulder. Diamondback looks him in the face. Smiling calmly. Jesse shifts his gaze to the Hitchhiker.
You're not going to look so good with your face ripped off. The Hitchhiker and the Highwayman look at each other in hilarious disbelief. They crack up.  51
Boy did we get lucky tonight. She is beautiful and he is so, so stupid. Jesse chuckles. The RADIO starts to play "STRANGERS IN THE NIGHT," sung b Sinatra.
A Peterbilt Eighteen Wheeler SHUDDERS past. "STRANGERS IN THE NIGHT" leaking out of the cab into the air.

Thick, gnarled fingers spin the knob of the RADIO in the dashboard. A small, round CAJUN TRUCKER with long, curly hair gazes the faces of his two passengers. He has a thick accent when he speaks and his words of Eng are limited. He zeros in on the station again. The Sinatra song bleeding through the scratchy speakers. The Cajun chuckles.
Sinatra. Good, huh? Mae lifts her pale face to his.
Good. Caleb smiles as the Cajun Trucker brings three bottles of out of a bag on the floor by his boots.
Here. We got Sinatra. We got good, solid truck. We got beer to enjoy open road.
Great. Thanks.

Drink up. He hands them both bottles of Bud. They artfully pretend to drink. He doesn't pretend. Mae nudges Caleb in the ribs.  52 He looks in her face. Her eyes say kill. Sympathetically. But soon. The Cajun Driver looks at them both and Mae averts her ey
You kids, you run from home? The girl nudges the farmboy.
Sure.
That okay by me. Sometimes home is bad. Me, I got truck for home. Good truck, huh? Caleb chews his lip. He's on the spot.
Some setup you got here. It's a real beauty. How do you fly it? The Cajun points to the various gears.
You drive truck before?
I've driven a semi. The mind is working behind the farmboy's eyes. The girl keeps her eye on him. The Cajun Trucker puts his hand on one of the many shifts

Semi, five gears. This, twelve gears. You got three go backwards, the rest, forward. Smoke? He knocks one up out of the pack. The Cajun Trucker lights it. Caleb grimaces at the idea of having to kill this chummy Mae keeps her hand on his hip.
Thanks.  53 Taking a butt. The Cajun Trucker lights it. Mae smiles, Caleb seems to unwind a bit.
The rest?
Shifting. You know how to shift. Is all. Watch. He goes up the gears. Steadily shifting, taking the speedometer up to 130.
Wow. Caleb shuts his eyes. Gathers his courage. Speaks.
Can you show me how to brake and stop the truck? The stocky man behind the wheel grins enthusiastically. Starting to downshift.

Now, this is most important thing with truck. You got two brakes. You get one brake for cab. This. An' one brake trailer. An' when you stop truck, you always use brake for trailer first. He throws that brake as he takes his foot off the gas. The truck starts to slow.
Then you use brake for cab. Or...
or? The truck decelerates onto the road shoulder.
The Peterbilt glides onto the gravel shoulder.  54
The Cajun turns his face to Caleb.

You jackknife. Cab stop. Trailer hit cab. No more truck. No more truck driver. Caleb is looking at the man very oddly. His eyes alarmed and anxious. Now that he has to make his move, he has the shakes. The Cajun Trucker is an easygoing guy, but the way this k looks is weird.
You got a problem? Mae clenches her fingers on Caleb's shoulders, urging him forward. The farmboy looks like he's going to puke. He shoves open the passenger door of the cab. Leaps out.

Caleb jumps down to ground level. Stumbles to his knees in the gravel. Heaving his guts with the gently bobbing oil pumps behind out in the fields. The Cajun Trucker leaps down and comes up behind the boy.

You can't drink and drive, huh boy? Caleb gets to his feet. The stocky man looks him in the face. The farmboy bares his teeth, but it's no good. He can't do it. Then he sees her. Mae. Hovering up behind the Cajun Trucker's shoulder. She uses her mouth.

An oil pump dips and rises. Mae stands before it. A gentle WIND ruffling her dress. Caleb is kneeling at her feet. His lips fastened on her wrist. Sucking.  55 Drinking. Sucking. Drinking. The fury almost rocking his body. A rabid fierceness with which he feeds. Mae gently strokes his head. Then nudges him away. He is locked tight. Draining her. Hearts pounding. She pushes with all her might. Rips his lips free. Her glistening eyes on his hungry face.

You could kill me if you drink too much. His upturned eyes gaping at her face. Mind spinning. Gulping air. The black night hangs heavy above. Stars dapple the surface. The oil pump keeps rising and falling.

A cloverleaf of freeways through the window. Sarah and Loy are eating breakfast at one of the booths. The little girl clicks open a pen and starts sketching a but recognizable picture of her brother on the back of hi horse. She starts to cry. Loy pushes away his plate of an uneaten hamburger and rea across the table. He cups her little face in his hands.
Shhh, honey. Come on, let's go make a phone call, see if anybody knows anything. She sniffles and nods.
Loy holds Sarah in his arms, the telephone receiver to hi
Eakers... Loy Colton here. Pause.  56
...You did? It's a positive make? His face brightens. His little daughter wipes her eyes.
Where was he? Hope, Kansas bus station... Cop said he was going home... Sarah winds her tiny hands around Loy's neck excitedly.

...You check the house?... He shoulda been there by now... No, I'm down in Waco, Texas. Guess I'm headin' in the wrong direction. Think I'll turn around, head North... No, you can't talk me out of it, Eakers. Just glad to know he's still out there. Thanks for your help... I'll stay in touch. He hangs up the phone. Sarah wears a big smile on her face as she tightens her a around her father's neck.
We found him, Daddy?
Almost. Hope flushes their faces as they head toward the Chevy Pi Driving into the hot afternoon sun.
TIRES ZOOMING over the tarmac.
TRAIN WHEELS RAGING across RAILS.

Caleb's head pushed closer and closer to the spark spitti wheels. Gritting his teeth, his eyes bulging up into Severen's fa The Savage One's hand in a vice grip around the farmboy's forcing him halfway out of the open box car. Sparks hitting Caleb's face.  57 He struggles beneath the remorseless grip. His strength no match for Severen's. In a ragged snarl Severen heaves the boy back up by the n

The Savage One throws the farmboy up against the wall, pi him with that same vice grip around the throat. Caleb sucks wind. Looking around him at the semi circle of darkening faces. To the icy blue eyes behind them. To Mae. His eyes plead. Hers tremor. She makes a move. Jesse revolves his silver head and gives her a look. Not a nice look. She freezes. Caleb stops breathing. The Silvered One moves forward.
One more night...! Lifting a long slender finger toward the farmboy's face.
Or I'm gonna get my wet dream, boy. Caleb swallows. Homer smacks his lips.
Why wait, we're gonna do it anyway. He ain't one of us, he don't belong! Besides... Turning an eye on Mae.
...He's so ugly it makes my gums ache. The girl comes forward. Squaring off in front of Jesse.
He needs more time, Jesse. Those steely eyes shift from the quivering farmboy to Mae A lip curls back.  58
I wonder about you, Mae... I shouldn't be wondering about you. A shiver runs through her system. Point taken. That long slender finger of the Silvered One sweeps back Caleb.

Ain't right for Mae to be carrying you, Caleb. Tonight you make a kill. How you do it is your business. You do it, or you're done. The Savage One takes his hand off the boy's throat. Giving him a look like he can't wait for the boy to screw Diamondback slides a harmonica out of her jacket and play slow, haunting melody. Then stops. Lifting her hypnotic eyes to the farmboy.

Done means dead without dying. Means you'll be real uncomfortable for a long, long time... Her lips return to the small metal instrument. The big rectangle of night rolling by the opening. Caleb moves to the door. Mae suddenly beside him. A match strikes flint nearby. Severen rolling a cigarette between his lips. Then hold on a cluster of lights in the distance. A big ROADHOUSE sitting not far from the tracks. Caleb follows Severen's gaze. And understands the Savage One's scarred face cracking in smile like a hatchet chop.
The freight hurtles by. A hundred cars long. Six figures leap off. Landing in a heap in the middle of a wheatfield, beneath rising moon.

Six tall silhouettes approach. A big, squat barn with a neon sign on the window.  59 A pickup, a tractor trailer, a Dodge Camper, and a choppe motorcycle parked out front. One look at the vehicles and you get a good idea of the clientele. Bad Country Music TWANGS out of the bar. The CLINK of pool cues on balls. The six of them stand in the shadows looking at the naile together roadside bar.
Let's hit the night in the face. Caleb takes a deep breath. They go in.

As soon as the six of them walk in, the place stops. A BIKER at the jukebox keeps his quarter. A fat, low to the ground TRUCKER at the bar turns a flatt face over thick shoulders to regard the fresh arrivals wi dull look. A COWBOY TEENAGER lifts his pool cue. The WAITRESS picks some empty glasses off the table in th booth. The BARTENDER CLICKS his teeth. A quiet comes over the joint. Severen winks and elbows Caleb in the ribs. Speaking in a voice loud enough for everybody to hear.

Look, shitkickers. I'll be Goddamned. C'mon, Caleb. Let's get some liquor in us. Maybe they'll look a little less stupid when everything's blurry. Caleb gets nervous. He waves friendly to the Biker. With the attitude of a sailor on a sinking ship about to submerge. The Biker doesn't wave back. Mae, Jesse, Diamondback, and Homer slide into the booth. The Silvered One catches the Waitress' eye and gestures f beer. The Savage One and the farmboy belly up to the bar. Severen slams his fist down. Making the surly Trucker spill his drink.  60
Bartender, gimmie two glasses of whatever shit you shove down these sucker's throats. The Bartender makes a big point of not looking at him. The Trucker looks at him though.
You spilled my drink.

You've had enough. By the way, were you born that ugly or is this your mama's idea of a joke? The Trucker does a slow burn. The temperature in the bar steadily rising. The Cowboy Teenager chalks his pool cue with a SQUEAKING cube. Severen clears his throat. Caleb starts to leave. The Savage One pulls him back. He picks up the glass of the Trucker. Addresses the Bartender.
Give him another. The Bartender pours the Trucker another drink. Severen nudges the Trucker.
Now, pay the man. The Trucker does a faster burn.
Bartender, that'll be a double shot of your very best watered down shit over here. He taps the bar. The Bartender stares the two of them in the face.

Do it again. Couple times. I'm tryin' to show him somethin'. The Trucker connects two roundhouse blows to the side of head. A double combination to his belly. The only thing that registers on Caleb's face is surprise sudden physical resilience.

...This is the best time I had since I nailed your mother backseat of your Daddy's truck. He was there watchin'. Severen taps him in the chest.

Severen's neck contracts as he GULPS and GULPS. With a high, wild cry, he heaves the dead, limp body of t Biker onto the jukebox with a CRASH. The Trucker doesn't move a muscle. The Bartender is white in the face.
What do you people want?

...Bout the same duration as the rest of your life. The farmboy starts walking away from the bar, stuperuous. He doesn't see the Bartender reach under the counter behi Picking up a double-barreled sawed-off .12 gauge shotgun. Vaulting the bar, landing on both feet, raising the weapo his eye. Oh shit. He's still standing. He's still alive. Utterly unhurt. Severen walks over. The Bartender is scared spitless, frantically trying to r The Savage One claps his hand on the boy's shoulder. Caleb's mouth tries to form words.
This is a kick, ain't it? Go sit down, I'll finish this up. Caleb dazedly has a seat on a barstool. The Bartender is almost sobbing as he wrestles with his g Severen wriggles his fingers at him.

The Bartender stumbles back, still on his feet. Raising his shotgun. The Savage One kicks out with his other boot. Slashing the man's throat a second time. The barman sways on his feet. The shotgun dropping from his grasp. With a rebel yell, Severen jumps into the air. Hitting the Bartender smack between the eyes with both bo Knocking the nearly severed head off his shoulders. The headless body sinks to the floor. The Savage One wipes his hands on his pants. Sings off key.

"Maaammma don't let your babies grow up to be cowboys. Don't let them strum guitars, and drive them old trucks, let them be doctors and lawyers, and such..."  65 Caleb just sits on the barstool, fingering the ragged sho blast in his chest. Wetting himself as he holds onto the pool cue for dear li She puts her eyes on Caleb. The girl takes one of the Cowboy's Teenager's hands in he She puts his other hand on her waist. Please dance with me. She leads him in a simple, shuffling, slow dance. Winding her hands down his back. Tenderly. The side of her face by the side of his. She turns him so that she can see Caleb over his shoulder The farmboy looks at her. Not liking that she is dancing with the other boy. He stands up off the stool. The COUNTRY MELODY permeating the abattoir of a barroom. The two of them dancing. She fingers the Cowboy Teenager's hair. His eyes are blank. Caleb comes toward them. Behind the boy's back. Mae slowly bobs and weaves with the boy on the floor.  66 Her eyes fixed to Caleb over his shoulder. Her lips turn up in a smile.

He's for you, Caleb. The farmboy looks around him to see all the eyes of the o on him. He looks at Mae. Knows it's now or never. He puts his hand on the boy's shoulder. The Cowboy Teenager screams his lungs out. He rips free of Mae. Covers his head with his arms. Dives headfirst through the neon Budweiser sign on the wi Caleb jumps out the window after him.

Get him, Caleb. The others grab her and get busy. Homer picks up the book of matches and strikes them one b chucking them onto the sawdust on the floor. Fires shoot up. Severen and Jesse make Molotov Cocktails out of the bottl the bar. Hurling them in combustion explosions of alcohol fire aga the walls. They torch the place and steal out the front doors.

The Cowboy Teenager running hell for leather. Caleb on his heels. The big, squat barn of a Roadhouse going up in flames. Five silhouettes emerge from the smoking structure. Moving to the black Dodge Camper in the parking lot. Severen hot wiring the vehicle with that smooth, practice efficiency. The others jumping in. The Camper quickly accelerating to the road.

Caleb's strong limbs flying over the blacktop. The Cowboy stares over his shoulder in terrific fear, cho for breath. Caleb gaining on him. The Camper and the others way way behind. He sees himself how he once was. Caleb freezes. He can't do it. Suddenly headlights from behind. The Dodge Camper bearing down. The Cowboy Teenager looks up. Through the glass to Jesse's grim face. He looks like he wants to cry. Then another pair of lights. This time from the other direction. A small SEMI with a flatbed wheels around the bend in the In a burst of speed, the Cowboy Teenager breaks for it. The Camper almost on Caleb's heels. Braking in a SQUEAL of smoking tires. As the Teenager leaps onto the flatbed barrelling by. Caleb runs fast as he can after the receding Truck. The Dodge Camper starting to make a U-turn. Suddenly blocked by an oncoming rush of Cars. Caleb's feet slap the dirt on the side of the road as the picks up speed and leaves him in its dust. Caleb pulls up. Looking from the disappearing Semi to the Dodge Camper st on the other side of the road. Then back to the Semi. Watching the red taillights of the Truck swallowed up by night. Traffic passing him. Then the Camper is abruptly at his side. A door cracks open. Long arms snatch him off the road.
Jesse squints into the faint light beginning to pale the the world. Vicious hands tug Caleb inside. Black looks. The Silvered One twists the Camper around and punches the

Now, Jess? Clicking very sharp teeth. Jesse's eyes boring through the windshield.  68
Fuckin' sun! Mae clings to the farmboy. Homer gives him a sickening face.
I think we should just leave your boyfriend out on the road and let him get hisself a suntan. Diamondback stares out the glass toward the gently paling
We better move our ass. The Silvered One fixes the boy's face in the rear-view mi

Horizonline becoming more and more distinct. The road ahead absolutely empty. Caleb stares down into his hands. Mae looks at him with soft eyes.

This rate we'll be lucky to make it at all. Goddamn kid you let get away's made this vehicle, he's gonna go straight to the cops and they're gonna be combin' the area. A deadly silence. That epic face straight front.
You both fucked us up.

Mae closes her eyes. The Dodge Camper streaking down the road. The sun now just ducking below the horizon. A tremor of fear rippling through every face. Blankets being tossed around. Tentacles of light piercing the glass. It looks like it hurts. Mae breathes deep. Lifts a strong face to the front.  69
You gonna talk, Jess, or you gonna get us out of the sun? Jesse looks at her through low lidded eyes.

...Okay. Soft and sweet. Mae shakes down to her bootstraps. Severen CRACKS his knuckles. Homer WHISTLES. Diamondback gives Mae a soul shaking smile. Then through the glass a Travel Court complex of little bungalows off to the side of the road.
"Bout time. Lifting his foot off the gas.
The Dodge Camper pulls up in front of the registration of The sun just about to peer over the edge of the world.

I'd like to rent one of your bungalows, Sir. The old man presses his hearing aid, nudging his head for
Wha...? The Silvered One notices the slow rise of light crawling the countertop toward his hand. He lays down a fifty dollar bill.  70

The key. A flicker of understanding in the Manager's face. Plucking a set of keys off the desk. Jesse grabs the key from him just as the sunlight lands u counter where his hand just was. He turns to go.
Hey, you were here b'fore once, wasn't ya? Lotsa years back? The Silvered One gives him a friendly grin as he walks ou

A picture pretty little box with windows and a door. Jesse hurriedly unlocks the door. The six figures hasten in. Slamming the door shut behind him. The reflection of the sliver of sun in the window slicing knife across the sharp side of the planet.

The sun high in the cloudless sky. In the courtyard between the bungalows, a DOG barks, play And scampers after a stick. He brings it back in his mouth to a bright and bushy tail SMALL BOY in sneakers and shorts. An ELDERLY COUPLE rock back and forth on the front porch of the bungalows. A laid-back, lazy morning. The Dodge Camper sits behind one of the quiet bungalows. The black paint baking in the hot sun. The little boy hurls the stick. It soars through the air. The pooch scrambles after it. The stick lands. The dog pads after it. A hand picks it up. The dog wags its tail. A POLICE OFFICER with a shotgun under his arm is holding stick. Three Patrol Cars creep into the courtyard, tires CRUMBLI gravel. The Policeman hurls the stick way in the other direction. The dog runs after it out of harm's way. The small boy is motioned onto the porch of his Grandpare cottage.  71 The Elderly Couple rise to their feet, holding the small them. The Police Officer gestures for the three Patrol Cars to him. The Cowboy Teenager is sitting in the backseat of one of cars, pointing nervously to the Camper and nodding. The Police Officer aims his eyes at the bungalow at the e the Travel Courts.

The three Patrol Cars mobilize in a fan formation around front porch. One more PATROL CAR moves into position out back. The doors are flung open. Assault rifles are readied in the arms of SEVEN COPS. Aiming at the walls and windows of the sleeping bungalow. Everything so quiet and calm on this nice summer morning BIRDS TWEETING. The Police Officer walks up to the front door. And KNOCKS.

Blackness. Curtains pulled tight. A deathly quiet. Six slumbering bodies. Caleb sprawled out on an overstuffed chair. Mae curled up in his arms. Jesse and Diamondback in the only bed. Severen sleeping standing up, leaning against the wall. Through the open bathroom door, Homer flat on his back in bathtub. A pillow over his face. A hard KNOCK on the front door. Homer throws the pillow from his face. Opens a sleepy lid. A VOICE from behind the door.
This is the police! Come out with your hands up! Severen's eyes pop open. Jesse leaps out of bed. Mae raises her head. Homer runs into the room. Diamondback rises to her feet.  72

You are surrounded! All eyes travel to Caleb. Caleb gets up. Worry in his eyes. Severen walks to the window, lifts a finger to the curtai pulls it back a crack. A single ray of sunlight explodes across his face like a spear. He jumps back. Screaming. Skin smoking. Hands pawing at his face.

Jesse yanks the Colt Peacemaker out of his belt and crack glass of the window with the butt. Caleb stands, head going back and forth as he watches the burst into action. Mae produces a small, pearl-handled .22 and a box of ammo her jacket. Diamondback has a sawed off twelve gauge in her coat. The Pale One swings up alongside one of the windows, smas out the glass with the stock. The Savage One plants his eyes on the farmboy as he grabs two pieces of a disassembled rifle out of his jacket. He screws on the barrel. Then he yanks a .357 Magnum out of his pocket. Fury scars his face as he holds it by the barrel for Cale take. The farmboy reaches for it. Severen flips the pistol and catches it by the handle. Meaning to use it on the new boy.
Oughta give you this end of it. Jesse shoots him a stern glance.
Give him the piece, Severen. Severen sighs. Hands over the gun. Caleb feels the weight and heft of the pice.  73
Severen steps right in front of the door. The rifle leveled in one hand at his waist. Finger on the trigger. Barrel fixed on the door. He plugs one ear with his finger and winks at the rest.
Rock n' Roll. He BLASTS a round through the door.
The Policeman standing in front of the door takes the hea calibre round square in the chest. It blows him clear off his feet. A shaft of sunlight shoots through the bullet hole in the

The shaft of sunshine streams through the door. Striking Severen smack between the shoulder blades. He is flung back against the wall and slides to the floor His shirt smoking. The others open FIRE out the windows.
The Seven Police Officers let loose with their assault ri Ravaging the walls and shattered windows with SHOTS. The air split by a DEAFENING DIN of gunfire.

A RIFLEBLAST rips two holes in the walls by Jesse's head reloads. Pinpricks of light blaze across the room. The Silvered One dives out of the way. A mirror on the wall fractures the light. Homer gets hit on the hand by a deflected ray. Skin bursts into flames. He yelps, running out of the way. Homer lifts his .38 to the window and starts pumping off Jesse shoots out the mirror to splintered glass smitheree Bullet holes swiss cheese the walls and roof. EXPLOSIONS of GUNFIRE rip through the wallpaper. Needles and lances of bright sunlight cats cradle the roo  74 The day comes through the holes and punctures in a maze o funnels. The six inside desperately keep up their volleys of gunfi They dodge, dive, duck and avoid the laser beams of light continue to cordon off the areas of the room they can mov fight back in. Caleb's gun isn't loaded and while he is popping in shell stray round from outside hits the box and scatters the cartridges. He glances over, while he frantically retrieves the bulle see Mae emptying her cute little .22 out the window along Homer. BULLETS RICHOCHET around the room with a piercing WHINE. The farmboy looks up and sees the rear window. The Camper is parked outside it. He thinks fast.
A hot sun burning overhead. A Police Car being RIDDLED with bullets. Cops diving for cover in a cloud of dust.
A momentary lull, the frantic reloading of guns. Caleb looks up into Jesse's sombre face.
I'm gonna go out there to get the Camper. Severen almost laughs.

That's a good one, asshole! A wall starting to splinter open with another round of GU BLASTS. Light burning across the floor. The others pressing back into dark corners. FIRING back as best they can. Jesse turns a narrow eye on Caleb.
You go outside, boy... He squeezes off a SHOT.  75
...They gonna be servin' you ona bun.
It's the best chance we got. Jesse barely blinks.
We'll cover ya. The farmboy nods. Severen shouts.
Asshole's gonna get himself killed. The Silvered One smirks at the Savage One.

So what do we got to lose? Git goin', boy, we'll cover ya. Jesse throws the car keys into Caleb's open palm. The farmboy yanks the bedspread off the bed and throws it his head. Mae reaches out with her hand, touching Caleb's arm. BULLETS flying left and right. She looks into his eyes. Caleb meets her gaze. Another EXPLOSION of GUNSHOTS. The farmboy spins on his feet, racing for the back window He leaps through the air and dives through the glass.

Caleb lands in a heap in the dirt. The sun attacks him beneath the bedspread. A single Policeman staking out the back starts SHOOTING a figure under the blanket. Caleb jumps to his feet and dodges bullets as he hurries Camper with the blanket flowing behind him like a cape. His hands holding the cover beginning to burn as the wick hits them. He starts to scream. The Camper only a few feet ahead. He claws forward. The Policeman takes careful aim. A bullet glances Caleb in the chest.  76 He keeps moving. Reaching the vehicle as the skin of his hands starts to s Ripping the door open and bursting inside.

Caleb kneels down behind the dashboard to shield himself the direct sunlight. He grips the steering wheel and slams the keys into the ignition. The engine FIRES up. He smashes his foot into the gas pedal. The sun blazes through the darkened windshield. He moans as the subdued light hits his face. Blackening the skin on his forehead. He ducks below the dash. Steering the vehicle straight ahead for the wall of the b riddled bungalow.

A tidal wave of deadly white light as the Camper breaks t the wall. Wood and glass raining down. The others wrap themselves in blankets they scrounge off as the light spreads through the room. The black Camper, covered with wallpaper and plaster, sit the middle of the floor. Caleb throws open the doors. Everyone is yelling loudly as they tear towards the vehic Slinging their guns in the back compartments, they all he other in.

Jesse heaves Diamondback onto the floor, covering her wit body. Severen gathers up his guns, clambering into the back compartment. Caleb hauls Mae into the seat beside him by a tug on her Homer grabs onto the rear bumper, crawling up the back fo open rear window. Screaming his lungs out as the bare sunlight bathes his s body. BULLETS RICOCHET off the front and sides of the Camper as assault continues from outside. One bullet cracks the window into a giant spiderweb.

Let's go!  77 Caleb drives his foot down on the accelerator. The car starts going. Homer claws his way onto the back of the vehicle, crying he loses his grip in the agonizing sunshine. Severen reaches out and drags him safely through the back window. They all duck down as the Camper piledrives through the f the building.

The nose of the Camper breaks through the front of the co like a huge black beast. Felling the screen door and powderizing the flower pots i path. The Policemen hold their fire for a moment and stare incredulously. The Dodge Camper lurches forward, carrying the frame of t cottage on its back like a shell. Ramming head on into a Police Car parked directly in fron The Policemen regain their senses, getting out of the way Camper. Pivoting and FIRING as they go. Fragments of the building raining off the roof of the veh They hurtle toward the tarmac of the open road. The Policemen jumping into their three remaining vehicles The Camper streaking out onto the blacktop. The Elderly Couple standing on the front porch exchanging glances of complete awe. The police cars swerving into single file formation and s out of the area with their cherrytops flaring. The Small Boy wide eyed in wonderment as he walks onto th driveway and watches them disappear in the settling dust. The Dog trots around with the stick between its teeth, ta wagging excitedly.

Three patrol cars swoop after their fleeing quarry like b prey. The object of their pursuit driving away from a setting s Red cherrytops igniting the livid sky. Two of the cop cars fan out. Windows rolling down. Shotguns aimed out.  78

Caleb is pummelled by the daylight piercing through the t glass windows. Blackening his skin in burned splotches. His hands fixed on the steering wheel, smoking. His foot hard on the gas pedal. Squinting over the dashboard, ducking down against the as of the sunshine. A SHOTGUN BLAST blows a spiderweb out of the windshield. The Camper charges down the road. The three Police Cars hurtling after it. Dust settles in a streak of red cherry tops.

The shield of the four walls of the vehicle are being bre by the shotguns. Laserlike beams of light shoot through the bullet holes. FIRING off round after round through the shattered glass back windshield.

The wound in his shoulder already healing up. The boy holding up as well as he can.
